newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: U.N. assembly to demand halt to Israeli settlements.
newsitem.headline: U.N. assembly to demand halt to Israeli settlements.

text.p: An emergency special session of the General Assembly is expected to adopt a resolution on Friday condemning and demanding an immediate halt to Israel's construction of a new settlement in East Jerusalem, captured during the 1967 Middle East war.
The draft, sponsored by about 30 mostly Arab and Islamic countries, is likely to be endorsed by an overwhelming majority of the assembly's 185 members, diplomats said.

The 10th emergency assembly -- the first since 1982 -- was convened on Thursday at the request of the Arab group of states under a 1950 procedure allowing an issue considered a threat to peace to be transferred to the assembly if a veto prevents the 15-nation Security Council from taking action.
There is no veto in the assembly, whose resolutions are not binding.

The United States used its veto on March 7 and again on March 21 to block Security Council resolutions calling on Israel not to proceed with the construction of 6,500 homes for Jews at a site between Jerusalem and Bethlehem called Har Homa in Hebrew and Jabal Abu Ghneim in Arabic.
While critical of the Israeli building project, the United States said differences between Israel and the Palestinians should be settled in bilateral negotiations.
On March 13, a non-emergency session of the General Asembly voted 130 to 2, with two abstentions, for a resolution calling on Israel to abandon its construction plan.
The latest resolution calls for "the cessation of all forms of assistance and support for illegal Israeli activities" in the occupied territories.

An earlier version, softened to gain the support of more European and other Western countries, would have specifically recommended that "all states prevent the provision of all assistance by their governmental agencies and their nationals to Israeli private or public establishments" involved in settlement activities.

The draft recommends that parties to the Fourth Geneva Convention, which prohibits settlements in occupied territories, "take measures, on a national or regional level ... to ensure respect by Israel" for the convention.
Secretary-General Kofi Annan would be asked to "monitor the situation and to submit a report" within two months. An earlier text would have asked him to send a team of U.N. observers to the area.

Another provision recommends that a comprehensive, just and lasting solution to the question of Jerusalem "should include internationally guaranteed provisions to ensure the freedom of religion and of conscience of its inhabitants" as well as "permanent, free and unhindered access to the Holy Places by the faithful of all religions and nationalities."
A paragraph included at the behest of some Western countries "rejects terrorism in all its forms and manifestations," in accordance with relevant U.N. resolutions.

The resolution calls for the emergency special session to be adjourned "temporarily" but authorises its resumption "upon request from member states." A previous special session on the question of Palestine in 1980 was resumed four times in the course of 1982.
